speaker: Neil
text: Welcome to 6 Minute English, where we introduce a colourful topic and six suitable items of vocabulary.

speaker: Tim
text: I’m Tim…

speaker: Neil
text: And I’m Neil. Why are you wearing a policeman’s hat, Tim?

speaker: Tim
text: To get me in the mood for our topic today – uniforms!

speaker: Neil
text: Well, the hat certainly suits you!

speaker: suits you
text: And if something suits you it looks good on you! Well, thanks, Neil. And funnily enough, I have a question for you on the subject of police hats! In the 19th century, police officers' top hats could be used…

speaker: suits you
text: a) to stand on,

speaker: suits you
text: b) as a weapon or

speaker: suits you
text: c) to protect their heads from the sun?

speaker: Neil
text: Well, they're kind of pointy so I’m going to say as a weapon.

speaker: Tim
text: OK. Let’s consider what the point of a uniform is. Why do some jobs have them while others don’t?

speaker: Neil
text: Well – The police, and other emergency services, like the fire brigade, and ambulance service – they need practical clothes to help them do their job.

speaker: Tim
text: People need to recognize them too, don’t they?

speaker: Neil
text: Yeah, that’s right. A uniform makes people stand out from crowd.

speaker: stands out
text: If something stands out it’s noticeable or easy to see.

speaker: tofit in
text: But uniform also allows you to fit in – it shows you belong to a particular group or organization – and people often enjoy that sense of community at work.

speaker: Tim
text: Do you think we should get some 6 Minute English T-shirts made, Neil?

speaker: Neil
text: Well, we share a sense of community without team T-shirts, Tim. Let’s listen to cultural historian, Joe Moran, talking about why wearing a uniform can also allow you to behave differently to the way you normally behave.

speaker: Joe Moran, cultural historian
text: It’s a role and a genre that you adopt and it’s kind of – it’s something that’s not quite you. It’s kind of a persona that you can put on. In Germany they call it ‘maskenfreiheit’, which is the freedom conferred by masks. There’s something about taking on what is very clearly a persona or professional role, that can be liberating, I think.

speaker: Genrepersona
text: So when you put on a uniform you are adopting a role or genre. Genre means a particular style. And a persona is a character you present to the outside world – as opposed to the person you feel like inside.

speaker: liberating
text: Joe Moran compares putting on a persona to putting on a mask. And he says this can be very liberating. But do you really think putting on a uniform liberates – or frees – us from the person we really are?

speaker: Neil
text: Maybe. If you’re shy, for example, a uniform might feel liberating because it allows you to behave more confidently. So, if you could choose a uniform and a new persona, what would it be, Tim?

speaker: Tim
text: Hmm. An airline pilot, I think. I’d look great in a blazer with brass buttons – and with the cap and mirror sunglasses. Hello, this is your captain speaking. We’ll shortly be arriving at LAX airport in sunny Los Angeles. Local time is 12.55 and it’s hot hot hot outside, so I hope you’ve packed plenty of sun cream.

speaker: Neil
text: OK Tim, stop, stop, stop, stop, stop! I can see you’d love being a pilot – or at least you’d love talking to your passengers!

speaker: Tim
text: What about you, Neil? What would you like to try on for size? A surgeon’s scrubs? A nun’s habit?

speaker: To try something on for size
text: To try something on for size means to decide whether it’s what you want or not. No Tim… I’d go for a chef’s apron, checked trousers, a tall hat.

speaker: Tim
text: I think the uniform would suit you, but are you good at cooking, Neil?

speaker: Neil
text: I’m an excellent cook. Now, I think we should have the answer to today’s quiz question, Tim.

speaker: Tim
text: Yes, I asked what a police officer’s hat could be used for in the 19th century.

speaker: Neil
text: And I said as a weapon.

speaker: Tim
text: Wrong, I’m afraid. From 1829 to 1839, Metropolitan Police officers wore a cane-reinforced top hat, which could be used as a step to climb or see over walls. I wonder if modern police hats are strong enough to stand on?

speaker: Neil
text: We’ll try yours later and find out. But now let’s go over the other key words we learned today.

speaker: Tim
text: OK. If something ‘suits you’, it looks good on you. For example, “Does this pilot’s uniform suit me, Neil?”

speaker: Neil
text: It suits you down to the ground, Tim! And that means it suits you very well!

speaker: Tim
text: Number two – If something ‘stands out’, it’s noticeable or easy to see.

speaker: Neil
text: “My colourful suit really stood out at the party.”

speaker: Tim
text: In a good way, I hope! OK, next item – ‘to fit in’ – means you belong to a particular group and are accepted by them.

speaker: Neil
text: “I never fitted in with the cool kids at school.”

speaker: Neil
text: I’m sorry to hear that, Tim! Maybe you weren’t wearing the right uniform? Number four is ‘persona’ – the character you present to the outside world – as opposed to the person you feel like inside.

speaker: Tim
text: “My work persona is confident and chatty but I’m actually rather shy.”

speaker: Neil
text: I’m learning a lot about you today, Tim!

speaker: Tim
text: They’re just examples, Neil. I don’t have a work persona – that’s the nice thing about our job – there’s no need to put on masks or personas.

speaker: Neil
text: Just the occasional hat…

speaker: Tim
text: Indeed. And a very nice hat this is too – I think I’ll keep it. Now, let’s finish the vocabulary! Number five – ‘liberating’ means feeling you can behave however you like.

speaker: Neil
text: For example, “Talking openly about your problems can be very liberating.”

speaker: Tim
text: And finally, ‘to try something on for size’ means to test something to decide whether you want it or not.

speaker: Neil
text: Our listeners can try these new vocabulary items on for size and decide whether they’ll be useful or not!

speaker: Tim
text: And if not, then please let us know by visiting our Twitter, Facebook and YouTube pages and telling us what you think!

speaker: Neil
text: Goodbye!

speaker: Tim
text: Bye!
